thread.title: Cats rule boards in big win over 36ers
thread.title_full: Cats rule boards in big win over 36ers

title: Cats rule boards in big win over 36ers
text:
NBL: Perth Wildcats beat Adelaide 36ers 79-66 in Adelaide BOTI NAGY PerthNow NBL: Perth Wildcats beat Adelaide 36ers 79-66 in Adelaide BOTI NAGY PerthNow Adelaide 36ers v Perth Wildcats at Titanium Security Arena. Nate Jawai slam dunks during the Wildcats 79-66 win. Picture: Sarah Reed 
ADELAIDE 36ers coach Joey Wright said winning the ­rebounding against Perth was essential for a second straight NBL victory at Adelaide Arena. 
That, coupled with some ­extended pressure would ­generate the fast break points synonymous with any Sixers success. 
But it was the Wildcats who won the boards in every quarter for a commanding 50-36 edge and when run was required, they turned on the afterburners and left the 36ers choking on their fumes, winning 79-66. Nathan Jawai of the Wildcats crashes into Daniel Johnson of the 36ers during the round one NBL match between Adelaide 36ers and the Perth Wildcats at Adelaide Arena on October 10, 2015 in Adelaide, Australia. (Photo by Morne de Klerk/Getty Images) Adelaide 36ers v Perth Wildcats at Titanium Security Arena. Daniel Carlin. Photo Sarah Reed Daniel Johnson of the 36ers blocks a shot by Casey Prather of the Wildcats during the round one NBL match between Adelaide 36ers and the Perth Wildcats at Adelaide Arena on October 10, 2015 in Adelaide, Australia. (Photo by Morne de Klerk/Getty Images) Daniel Johnson of the 36ers steals the ball from Shawn Redhage of the Wildcats during the round one NBL match between Adelaide 36ers and the Perth Wildcats at Adelaide Arena on October 10, 2015 in Adelaide, Australia. (Photo by Morne de Klerk/Getty Images) Brendan Teys of the 36ers and Matthew Knight of the Wildcats competes for the ball during the round one NBL match between Adelaide 36ers and the Perth Wildcats at Adelaide Arena on October 10, 2015 in Adelaide, Australia. (Photo by Morne de Klerk/Getty Images) Daniel Johnson of the 36ers blocks a shot by Casey Prather of the Wildcats during the round one NBL match between Adelaide 36ers and the Perth Wildcats at Adelaide Arena on October 10, 2015 in Adelaide, Australia. (Photo by Morne de Klerk/Getty Images) Jermaine Beal of the Wildcats goes for the basket during the round one NBL match between Adelaide 36ers and the Perth Wildcats at Adelaide Arena on October 10, 2015 in Adelaide, Australia. (Photo by Morne de Klerk/Getty Images) Matthew Hodgson of the 36ers is blocked by Matthew Knight of the Wildcats during the round one NBL match between Adelaide 36ers and the Perth Wildcats at Adelaide Arena on October 10, 2015 in Adelaide, Australia. (Photo by Morne de Klerk/Getty Images) 1 of n 
From 63-63 with 4:45 left — it was 53-53 at the last break — the fans were braced for a thrilling finish, erased entirely when Perth’s guns fired up. 
Shawn Redhage, who was 1-of-7 from the floor, suddenly swished his only triple of the night. Then Jermaine Beal — Adelaide’s nemesis in the 2014 Grand Final — made it back-to-back threes, an off-the-ball foul giving Redhage two additional free throws. 
When Beal stole the ball from Ebi Ere for 73-63, it was over, Perth’s star guard with 12 last quarter points in his 18-point game-high. Other Stories
